name: LSPM J2116+0234
scenarioDescription:
The LSPM J2116+0234 Exoplanetary System

LSPM J2116+0234 is a star with 0.43 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.43 times its radius. It is located 57.53 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 2 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

LSPM J2116+0234 is known to have 1 exoplanets in orbit around it.

LSPM J2116+0234 b

LSPM J2116+0234 b was discovered by the Calar Alto Observatory observatory using the radial velocity method. Its discovery was announced in 2019-05. Its semi-major axis is 0.09 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 14.44 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, LSPM J2116+0234.

Its eccentricity, the extent to which the shape of the exoplanet's orbit departs from a perfect circle (Earth's is 0.0167, which is why the shape of Earth's orbit is circular rather than oval in appearance), is 0.183, which means that when LSPM J2116+0234 b is at is at its closest point to its host star, 0.07 astronomical units separates the two, and when it is at its farthest point, this number is 0.10. In the case of Earth, these numbers are 0.9832899 and 1.0167103 respectively.

The mass of LSPM J2116+0234 b is 13.30 times the mass of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, LSPM J2116+0234 b is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system LSPM J2116+0234, which contains 1 planets and was discovered by Calar Alto Observatory.
